#Text=Boaz Mahune
#Text=Lahainaluna Mission
#Text=Seminary , c. 1840s .
#Text=Boaz Mahune ( died 1847 ) was a 19th-century politician and civil servant of the Kingdom of Hawaii .
#Text=He helped contribute to the writing of the 1840 Constitution of the Kingdom of Hawaii and was the author of its preamble the He Olelo Hoakaka , or the Declaration of Rights of 1839 .
#Text=Biography
#Text=Born in the early 1800s , Mahune was a member of the lesser strata of Hawaiian nobility , subordinate to the high chiefs or aliʻi . [ 1 ]
#Text=He was a cousin of Paul Kanoa , who served as Governor of Kauai from 1846 to 1877 . [ 2 ]
#Text=He adopted the name " Boaz " from the Biblical figure after his conversion to Christianity .
#Text=It was often spelled as Boas . [ 1 ] [ 3 ]
#Text=He was a member of the first class of Lahainaluna Seminary under the school 's first principal Lorrin Andrews .
#Text=His classmates included historian David Malo , royal advisor Jonah Kapena , and royal diplomat Timothy Haʻalilio .

#Text=Graduating in 1835 , he was considered one of the most brilliant scholars in the school and was one of the ten chosen to remain as monitors , teachers in the children 's school and assistants in translating . [ 2 ]
#Text=Along with a few of his fellow graduates from Lahainaluna , he assisted King Kamehameha III and his chiefs in the writing of Hawaii 's first constitution .
#Text=Mahune became one of the secretaries and advisors to the King .
#Text=He was responsible for writing the first draft of the Declaration of Rights of 1839 , originally written in the Hawaiian language .
#Text=After several round of changes by the king and his councilors , it was published June 7 , 1839 . [ 4 ] [ 2 ]

#Text=Considered Hawaii 's Magna Carta , it laid down the inalienable rights of the people , the principles of equality of between the makaʻāinana ( commoner ) and the aliʻi ( chiefs ) and the role of the government and law in the kingdom . [ 5 ]
#Text=Along with the Declaration of Rights , many of the laws codes within the constitution were of Mahune 's authorship .
#Text=Mahune wrote most of the laws concerning taxation . [ 4 ]
#Text=King Kamehameha III specifically directed him to conform them to the principles of political economy that he learned in Lahainaluna . [ 2 ]

#Text=The bulk of Mahune 's work and ideas were influenced by his missionary education at Lahainaluna and the United States Declaration of Independence , [ 6 ] although recently doubts have been cast upon the actual authorship of the Declaration and the majority of the Constitution .

#Text=Hawaiian historian Jon Kamakawiwoʻole Osorio believe that it was American missionary William Richards , who was mainly responsible and that Mahune and Jonah Kapena , were only assistants to the creation of the Declaration of Rights . [ 7 ]
#Text=Mahune served as the manager for the King 's sugarcane plantation in Wailuku on Maui , which proved to be unsuccessful .
#Text=Serving as a judge in Lahaina for a period of time , he returned to Honolulu in 1846 , where he went back to working for the government as a civil servant .
#Text=In March 1847 , Mahune died after a distressing and painful illness of several months .
#Text=He died without writing a will ; his landholdings had been quite extensive including properties in each of the main islands showing his rank and favor in the royal court . [ 2 ]
